text: Morning light, lemon and faint through the trees of HAMPS HEATH. A SQUIRREL runs along the BRANCH of a tree. OCTOBER 1818.

A THREAD of COTTON noses it’s way through the eye of the needle. FANNY BRAWNE aged 18 is SEWING by FIRST LIGHT while her 9 year old sister MARGARET sleeps. Her stitches are confide intricate and fast. The WHITE MUSLIN she is sewing is delicate and fine. The glint of the STEEL NEEDLE as it weaves then pulls, weaves then pulls a trail of perfect stitches.

MRS BRAWNE 40 enters the KITCHEN dressed to go out. Fanny the MAID CHARLOTTE and little Margaret are all sewing different parts of Fanny’s white muslin dress. Samuel, he 14-year old brother, sits apart munching toast.
Have you forgot we are going to Mr and Mrs Dilke for tea? We are to meet Mr Brown’s poet friend Mr Keats.

No I have not forgot. Can you help Margaret, the stitches must be small and exactly even. Mrs Brawne takes over from her youngest daughter. FANNY (cont’d) What if Mr Brown has already poisoned Mr Keats against me? I shall not be afraid to take them on in wit. If I am in the mood I could lash them both.
Why not ignore Mr Brown?
He provokes me! Mama it is his game. I must defend myself.
Fanny finishes some intricate hair arrangement, with the of little Margaret, who passes the pins to her mother who securing them.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 2.
The maid finished pressing the dress. She carries it upstairs over her arms like a baby.

location: WASHING LINES AT THE BACK OF ELM COTTAGE

text: Fanny, a vision in white, walks elegantly between her fam out onto Hampstead Heath, past the WASHER WOMEN and a maz WASHING LINES.

Fanny and her family walk down the Heath between CLOTHES spread out on BUSHES with a distant London beyond. They p a FAMILY evicted from their house with their possessions, BED, WARDROBE and TABLE for sale. The air is SMOKE FILLED from the burning of AUTUMN LEAVES.

The Brawne family group turn into the gate of WENTWORTH HOUSE. Fanny dauntless, her head high, her cheeks pink an ready for battle. MARIA DILKE greets them at the door, adoring Fanny’s new dress and it’s petal embroidery. Fanny greets everyone warmly, MR DILKE and little CHARLES their son. MR BROWN joins the group. Fanny frowns and looks away.
Ah, the very well stitched little Miss Brawne in all her detail.
Where is Mr Keats?
I'm afraid he is not joining us. He is next door in Mr Brown’s half of the house. Mr Brown puts out his hand to Fanny who moves past, ignor him.
What is this? What have I done? How have I offended?
I don’t shake hands with an enemy.
An enemy? What have I done to you?  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 3.
You do nothing to me, or for me and that is how I prefer to keep it. Mr Brown holds up his arms in mock wonder, enjoying teasi Fanny as he might a lap dog.
What!?
All right, your offence is to my fashion to which I am “so helpless slavish!”
I didn’t say that, Mrs Dilke? I never would say such nonsense. I have been ill quoted. The gathering moves into the DRAWING ROOM where tea is served. Maria is bowing her head guiltily.
Baiting...baiting...
...“her obsession with flounce and cross stitch?”
Cross stitch? Miss Brawne I don’t even know what it means, I have been wrongly used.
I feel the same about your poems Mr Brown, I know nothing of what they mean. In fact, they have the quality of your cigar, they puff, smoke and dissolve leaving nothing but irritation...
Fanny why not talk to one of us you hold in higher favour?
Mr Brown sets out to irritate and he is successful, now I set out to demolish and I am only begun.
Ohhh...
Fanny take this tea to poor Mr Keats, he is in very poor spirits.
Oh. Will he have sugar?  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 4.
He is composing and does not want disturbing.
It is my finding in the business of disturbing you are the expert.
Fanny that is too far.
I am praising him!
Fanny...
What now I am restrained because I compliment him too much? I withdraw. Let someone else take Mr Keats’s tea, I want to be left alone to examine the length of my stitches.

Please Fanny I want you to go, I am wanting to know what you shall say about Mr Keats. I have been waiting two weeks that I may enjoy your opinion. I cannot look upon him without smiling and he is quick with his thoughts though now they are mostly sad.
His brother Tom is not at all better, very diminished. Fanny’s sympathy is engaged.
Mr Keats nurses him alone. It is difficult work.
Are there no other family members?
No. The parents are both dead. There is only a much younger sister and a brother who emigrated to America.
How old is Tom?
Only 19, very painful and Keats is not much older.

I am so sorry.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 5. INT. MR BROWN’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON 9 Fanny stops mid corridor to check her hair and self in th hall glass. She is possessed, neither pleased or displeased with her appearance and dispassionate in her attention. Outside Mr Brown’s DOOR Fanny stops to knock and then to the handle but KEATS surprises her by pulling the door suddenly open (expecting Mr Brown). Keats and Fanny are eye to eye, each other’s petite equal They laugh. The tea sloshes.

You like jokes Mr Keats? I like jokes. I hope we shall play some on each other. Mr Brown I warn you, does not like my jokes, he complains I care for nothing but fashion. Should you like cake? Fanny turns to leave.
And what shall be said of me? You have come to spy.
I came to bring you tea.
How will you describe me? My character?
I am not the least interested in your character.
My jacket then or my pantaloon?
You need a new jacket that is what I would say.
That is all?
That it should be of velvet.
Tell me Miss Brawne, how are you so sure?  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 5A.
All that I wear I have designed and sewn myself. Is it not well done? (MORE )

10 11 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 6. FANNY (cont'd) I am often told I am clever to exception about design, I have originated the pleated edge upon the ribbon. It is charming and it has been copied... Mr Brown enters the room and sits at his spot at the WRIT DESK opposite Keats, pushing his chair back to look at Fa

Has she annoyed you sufficiently? She has done brilliant well with me. Men's room, men's room, OUT, thank you. Poets writing. Mr Brown picks up his PEN and acts writing. Fanny leaves calmly as if Mr Brown was not scuttling her.
Goodbye minxstress.
My stitching has more merit and admirers than your two scribbling’s put together.
Ohhhh. Ohhhh.
And I can make money from it.
Ouch!
Margaret and Samuel make their way to the BOOKSHOP, caref not to catch the eye of the HUNGRY and HOMELESS.

The BELL on the BOOKSHOP DOOR rings. Margaret and Samuel enter. Their boots clunk on the boards of the quiet shop, they walk to the counter. There is no-one there, they sta in front of it. A VOICE speaks from a shelf behind.
Yes? Samuel moves to the counter.
Have you got John Keats’s poem book Endy...
Endymion? I’ve not heard much good about it. I’ve not sold one and took twenty.  12 13 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 7. The SHOPKEEPER takes a copy from a tallish pile.
My sister has met the author. She wants to read it for herself and decide if he is an idiot or not.

Fanny at home in her room sews the tiny pleats of a TRIPL MUSHROOM PLEATED COLLAR. Her needle weaving in and out, t drawing the thread through. Her eyelashes caught in the P WHITE SUN. Standing in her PETTICOAT, she holds the almos complete collar to her neck and checks it’s effect in the glass. She gently tilts her head to the side and points h toe.
Margaret and Samuel come upstairs and enter Fanny’s bedro Margaret takes off her COAT and sits. Fanny's steel needl pauses.

Unwrap it. Margaret takes the BROWN PAPER from the book. Fanny watch She takes the book in her own hands, turns it over, opens to the title page. Then passes it back to Margaret. FANNY (cont’d) Read it. Her needle weaves in and out of the pleats, drawing it’s thread behind it.

“A thing of beauty is a joy for ever: Its loveliness increases; it will never Pass into nothingness; but still will keep A bower quiet for us, and a sleep Full of sweet dreams, and health, and quiet breathing. Therefore, on every morrow, are we wreathing A flowery band to bind us to the earth” Fanny’s eyes stop and go deeply inside, she is listening. Her needle again weaves in and out of the fine pleat. She sewing faster. MARGARET (cont'd) “Spite of despondence, of the inhuman dearth”  14 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 8.

Stop. Margaret stops and looks to Fanny. Fanny stops sewing. FANNY (cont’d) I am completely lost... Fanny takes the book from Margaret. FANNY (cont’d) “...yes, in spite of all, Some shape of beauty moves away the pall From our dark spirits.”

The ROYAL ARTILLERY MESS at WOOLWICH, a DANCE and Fanny i the centre of it in her new gown. She dances with a studi grace. The effect is elegant yet mannered. In the interval she sights an under dressed Keats sitting back, ignoring the dancers absorbed in his thoughts. Near him Mr Brown and their friend REYNOLDS and his SISTERS ta loudly. Fanny whispers to her younger brother Samuel. Samuel slouches over to Keats.
My sister Miss Brawne wishes to greet you Mr Keats.
And where is she? Fanny is all alone waiting for him strategically posed by large ORNATE MIRROR near the dining hall.
“A thing of beauty is a joy for ever: Its loveliness increases; it will never Pass into nothingness;” Keats looks surprised.
You have read Endymion?
I wanted to adore it.
But you hate it?
I cannot say.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 9.
Are you afraid to speak truthfully?
Never.
Well tell me then.
No. I am not at all clever with poetry.
Neither it seems am I. Still I have hope for myself. What do you make of my hope Miss Brawne?
I think hope very useful.
But...
But hope and results are very different. One does not create the other.
Could practice help?
Yes it might. I was not always able to stitch so well.
Ah ha, I must practice my stitches. Fanny looks at Keats.

Let me do the sewing, I have such a start. This is the first frock in Woolwich or Hampstead to have a_ triple-pleated-mushroom collar. Keats looks about to realise there is only Fanny, himself their reflection.

Behind you I see one I fear to be identical. Fanny disconcerted, turns to see her own reflection, she laughs very pleased with the joke. She sees a GROUP of MILITARY MEN, dance partners searchin for her. She puts her back to them so she may finish talking.  15 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 10.

My card is completely full; three I have met before and are suitors. Mr Tarrant is scaring me with his talk of estates and his dogs, he has eleven. Maman says it is possible to love almost anybody and I will come to understand that.
Even Mr---?
Tarrant? Yes, isn’t that a miracle? But you don’t dance Mr Keats. I love to dance.
I don’t feel like dancing..
Your brother is still ill?
He is no better.
I have thought of him often and wish to make him something. Would lemon wafers be agreeable?
He would like so much that you had thought of him.

My Papa was ill for as long as I can remember. He died when I was still a child. Fanny tears up. She takes out a small WHITE EMBROIDERED HANDKERCHIEF and pats her eyes. The TWO MILITARY MEN spot Fanny and come over. Keats bows and departs while Fanny is led out on to the d floor. She has recovered herself and is dancing with quaintly exaggerated hand movements aimed at affecting a personal stylishness. The Reynolds sisters notice and comically impersonate. Apparently for Keats’s benefit. He is not amused by them or by Fanny but is alone and aliena

On the kitchen table Fanny and the maid are grating LEMON RIND. Dabbing WAFER MIX onto an OVEN TRAY. Stoking the FIRE. From the cooked wafers Fanny tosses all but the mos perfect onto a rubbish heap. She lines a BASKET with LINE Then pausing, she turns from the table.  16 17 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 11. Quickly she swoops on Margaret’s frock where she snips a LEMON RIBBON off her neckline and begins to tie it decoratively on the basket.

Mother! Fanny has taken my ribbon and she never asked. Mama! Margaret goes in search of her mother who she finds in th hall way. MARGARET (cont'd) She has cut my ribbon. Mrs Brawne enters the kitchen to see a mess of SHATTERED DISCARDED wafers and Fanny tying the ribbon on her basket 20 PERFECT wafers.
What are you doing Fanny?
I am trying to bring some comfort to a dying man. Mrs Brawne picks up one of the discarded wafers from a hu stack.
What dying man? Where are you taking them?
I cannot offer poor Mr Keats’s brother anything that is not perfect.
But so many of them look quite well.
Mama, quite well! He may die. I cannot offer him anything but our most beautiful and our best.
Fanny carries the BASKET of wafers as the THREE young Brawne’s walk up the path to Wentworth House.
Inside the house they walk down the corridor to Mr Brown’ apartment. Fanny knocks.
No thank you, poets at work.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 12.
It is me, Miss Brawne. I have something to deliver to Mr Keats.
Leave it at the door.
Is Mr Keats not there?
I am here.
We are working Miss Brawne.
I have something for Mr Keats's brother. Heavy footsteps. Mr Brown opens the door. Fanny holds out basket with a LACE NAPKIN laid over the top. Mr Brown whi off the LACE COVER and pinches a wafer.
Mmmm. ..delicious...
You vile, disgusting, ape! A sad Keats turns his head towards Fanny at the door and watches listlessly.
Invite Miss Brawne inside. Let them all come in. Mr Brown stands aside, gobbling his wafer.
Be careful you enter the apes cage, (mimicking a monkey) Hoo, hoo, hoo.
You are invisible to me, you idiot, you...
Come and sit here, next to me Miss Brawne. My prospects in the world feel very faint.

This room is so poorly cared for. It is half night in here for want of pulling your drapes back. She passes over the wafers.  18 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 13. FANNY (cont’d) Please try one. I am anxious they will cause him to choke. Keats takes one. Mr Brown puts his hand into the basket Fanny whips it away. FANNY (cont’d) No! They are baked for someone very ill. Try another and I swear I shall bite you.
Ohhh, I’m very scared.
Take care, she has sharp teeth. She has sunk her fangs into my poor poem and shook it apart.
I am very sorry I could not love your Endymion completely Mr Keats. Perhaps I did not say but I thought the beginning of your poem something very perfect. Fanny turns to go.
No, don’t leave us. You can see for yourself, nothing is happening. All day we lie about the room begging for inspiration. Tell me what I must do.
There is something sordid and menacing that I don’t at all enjoy in the atmosphere. I am in a hurry to get myself away. I feel I am inside a cage with two monkeys.
We monkeys just want a little company. Mr Brown steals another wafer. Fanny spins away.
How dare you!

Fanny, Margaret and Samuel walk back fast through the Hea A great GUST of WIND sends the AUTUMN LEAVES spiralling upwards. Keats, flush faced is jogging after them but somewhat behind them. He has Fanny’s basket in his hand.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 13A.
If we've finished tiffing, come and say “hello” to Tom, it might cheer him.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 14.
We will have to ask Mama.
No we don’t Toots.
Yes we do, isn’t that so Samuel? We have to stay together. Samuel shrugs. Fanny walks off.
Well then, I am going and you will have to come with me. Keats stands at the junction of many tracks.
Should you like to go by the pond or through the wood? I have explored all these paths which are more in number than your eyelashes.
My eyelashes? Fanny bats her eyelashes and laughs. She walks beside Kea FANNY (cont’d) It amazes me that you can sit opposite Mr Brown all day. I have never heard him say one thing of wit. Not one!
You favour wit?
I rate it the highest.
You like the fashionables?
Yes, I do.
Men who say things that make you start without making you feel?
No, things that are amusing.
I know these dandy’s, they have a mannerism in their very eating and drinking, in their handling of a decanter.  19 20 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 15.
You are making an attack on me.
No, I am defending Mr Brown’s generous good heart.
By attacking myself?
Forgive me. I have been too long at my brother's sick bed.
Can we not still appreciate clever humour?
What witty thing can be said of a nineteen year old drowning in his own blood? Fanny suddenly realises the seriousness of Tom’s illness.
Nothing, nothing at all. EXT. KEATS’S APARTMENT WELL WALK - DAY 19 The three Brawne’s led by Keats, arrive in the COURTYARD his rented apartment in WELL WALK. Keats leads them in.
Oh thank God! He’s been calling out for you.
Excuse me. INT. TOM’S ROOM WELL WALK - DAY 20 He enters TOM’S ROOM In the other room Fanny glimpses Keats holding his pale, groaning brother who struggles to breathe. It looks grim, hopeless.
I want to go. I want to leave. It smells.
Shush, or I’1l cut your hair in the night. Keats comes back out looking pale and saddened.
He is feverish and cannot speak.  21 22 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 16.
Should I call a nurse?
I trained for 5 years as a doctor, there is nothing to be done. Tears spring to Fanny’s eyes, she gives Keats the LEMON WAFERS.
The wafers.
Wentworth House in the evening. Both sides of the house a LIT UP for an evenings entertainment. PEOPLE are arriving walking up the path to the house.
Inside Fanny and her family are removing their PELISSES a OVERCOATS with the Dilke’s help when Keats arrives. There are lots of “Good Evenings” and jollities.
I don’t see your bassoon, I hope you have not forgotten it.
Not at all, it’s in my waistcoat pocket. Fanny watches Keats arrival keenly.
Mr Keats.
Hello Minx.
How is Tom? Keats looks away from Fanny suddenly anxious.
Gentlemen of the orchestra to the left, Ladies to the right.
Mr Keats how is...
Don’t ask me of Tom, Minx. The only good I can do is say how I love him.  23 24 25 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 17.
Rehearsal has begun. Hurry on gentlemen.

Let us start with some claret to tune the instruments. Mr Dilke walks after Keats playing an invisible violin. Fanny watches them disappear. INT. DILKE’S DRAWING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - EVENING 23 The ladies, Mrs Brawne, Mrs Dilke, the Reynolds sisters, Fanny and the children sit quietly together in the Dilke’ drawing room. The Reynolds sisters play CARDS with the ol women while Fanny sews a flower pattern onto a piece of l From their room they can hear the loud voices of the MEN the opposite wing. Fanny's needle picks out the outline o the leaf. INT. DILKE’S KITCHEN WENTWORTH HOUSE - EVENING 24 In the kitchen Mrs Dilke, her COOK and Fanny carry PLATES PICKLES, CHEESE and MEAT through into the men’s room. Fan seeks out Keats who is drowning his sorrows in play, he a another friend, MR SEVERN the artist, are having a duel u CELERY STICKS. Fanny puts the plates down on the TABLE an leaves with the others unnoticed. INT. DILKE’S DRAWING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - EVENING 25 Fanny and Mrs Dilke come back into the insular world of ladies.
We were just telling Mrs Brawne of John Keats’s review in Blackwoods.
We did not know there were people left who had not read it.
You have not seen it?
In this house we do not acknowledge it.
Was it so very bad?
I can’t bring myself to remember...  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 18.
It has stuck in my mind. “...no man, whose mind has ever been imbued with the smallest knowledge or feeling of classical poetry or classical history, could have...”
“,..profaned and vulgarised every association in the manner which has been adopted by this “son of promise”...”
Did they not admire the opening? The opening was perfect even I could know that.
Do you like poetry Miss Brawne?
No. Poems are a strain to work out - and I never can tell if I have worked them well. The Reynolds sisters titter. JOHN REYNOLDS enters the room. He is a lawyer poet friend Keats
John we are talking or about to talk of your defence of Mr Keats’s poem Endymion.

Yes... “I have clung to nothing, loved a nothing, nothing seen or felt but a great dream! OT have been presumptuous against love against the sky, Against all elements, against the tie of mortals each to each.” The rhythm is beautiful and unique. There are rhymes but not on the beat, they are quiet but binding and the repetitions set you up to fly. “I have clung to nothing, loved a nothing, nothing seen.”
Reynolds indicates the expanse of flight. JOHN REYNOLDS (cont'd) Here you come out “Or felt but a great dream...”
It’s beautiful.
There are immaturities but also immensities and that is what they didn’t say.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 19.
It was said, you said it brother.
Thank you.
Indeed you said it beautifully.
Very bravely. Mr Severn walks into the room.
Ladies the Hampstead Heathens are about to begin. Reynolds?

Not me, I’m expelled. 26 INT. MR BROWN’S ROOMS WENTWORTH HOUSE - EVENING 26 The AUDIENCE of lady folk squeeze into Mr Brown’s CANDLE rooms. The fifteen gentlemen are formally assembled. Keat Mr Brown and their friends perform a well known MOZART PI with their human orchestra. Fanny watches quietly focusin on Keats. The Reynolds sisters enter confidently into the festivities, “ohhhing” and “ahhhing”, laughing affectedly

Fanny and her brother and sister are having dance instruc from their very effeminate FRENCH DANCE MASTER. They use BOX MIRROR to correct their posture. Through the window, Fanny notices a teary faced Maria Dilke gesturing to Mrs Brawne who leaves. The class continues with Fanny dancing the formal style of the time but her feelings overwhelm h Tears fill her eyes.

Fanny, tempo. Un deux trois, un, deux, trois. Fanny has stopped still. Tears roll down her cheeks. She leaves the room. DANCE MASTER (cont’d) Mademoiselle... She walks down the hall to the kitchen where Maria Dilke being comforted by Mrs Brawne and a CUP of TEA.
Is it Tom? Has he died?  28 29 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 20. Maria Dilke turns and nods her head. Fanny leaves, pushin past Toots.
Fanny vient de quitter la classe de danse. (Fanny just left the class.)

Laisse-la. (Leave her.) INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM ELM COTTAGE - DAY 28 Fanny pulls out a piece of IVORY SILK. She slices through the material with SCISSORS. Mrs Brawne enters the room. She watches Fanny sobbing lou as she works, then bends to help Fanny pin TWO rectangles the silk together. Fanny’s needle is thread with a light GREEN COTTON. Her needle flies in and out making a line of grass. Out of th grass she sews stems and wild flowers. INT. BRAWNE’S PARLOUR/HALL/FRONT DOOR ELM COTTAGE - DAY 2 John Keats, Charles Brown and the Brawne's sit in the Brawne’s PARLOUR. Fanny is silent. Mr Brown talks to Mrs Brawne who is all solicitude.

I woke with the strange sensation of someone holding my hand. I opened my eyes and there was John. I knew immediately what had happened and then he said “Tom died at 8 o'clock quietly and without pain.” Of course Mr Keats can’t go on living there, so I have invited him to stay with me. Mr Brown stands, sighing, looking towards a numb Keats. MR BROWN (cont'd) Aghuh, we have a long schedule of visits. Fanny sits with her eyes downcast. Keats is watching her sensing her disappointment that they are leaving so soon.
I don’t want to interfere with your city plans but you are most welcome to have dinner with us. We have provided and set the table...
Minx? Are you unwell? I have never seen you so quiet.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 20A.
I am sad for your brother Mr Keats.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 21. Fanny hands him the silk embroidered PILLOW SLIP wrapped BLACK CLOTH.
She has been sewing it all through the night. Keats begins to unwrap it, enough to see the beautiful stitching and the simple pattern of wild flowers on the e
I am afraid I will break down. Tell me what it is?
It is a pillow slip.
Then I shall rest Tom’s head upon it.
Keats, the Reynolds are expecting us.
I will catch you up. Thank you. Keats kisses the pillow slip. Mr Brown has come across and is whispering in Keats ear.

Let us get out of here. It is a loud whisper, loud enough so that Fanny and Keats both hear. Fanny, shamed, watches as the two men continue discussing, she catches phrases, “would like to stay”, “w are expected by HAYDEN and LAMB”. Keats puts on his COAT.
Invite me again, alone.
Come for Christmas.
Shouldn’t you ask your mother?
No, what one of us wants we all wish for, that is how we are. Keats looks unconvinced. FANNY (IN FRENCH) (cont’d) Maman I have invited Mr Keats for Christmas dinner.  30 31 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 22.
Yes, Mr Keats, please do join us. Margaret and Samuel loudly enthuse.
Yes. Hurrah. Please do, please!

But Marianne Reynolds invited us for Christmas. You were there when she said it, remember they are having musicians? The Brawne children are crestfallen. Fanny defiant. MR BROWN (cont'd) I am sorry to spoil things.
Not at all. Wherever Mr Keats is happy we are happy for him.
Why can’t he be happy with us?
Because Mr Brown wants Mr Keats all to himself.
I am merely remembering to Mr Keats a previous engagement. Fanny turns and walks back inside Elm Cottage. MR BROWN (cont'd) You are walking away Miss Brawne! I thought we were conversing...
Fanny and her sister sew in silence.
Mrs Brawne and Charlotte the maid work quietly together making MINCE PIES. A LETTER is delivered to the kitchen door. Charlotte give the letter to Mrs Brawne.  32 33 34 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 23.
Mrs Brawne comes into the drawing room with the open lett Margaret and Fanny look up but Fanny does not pause in he neat small stitches
“Dear Mrs Brawne, May I yet join you for Christmas? I have not the health or the heart to be anywhere but with a family such as your own.” John Keats.

Fanny, the maid, Mrs Brawne and Margaret prepare the Christmas dinner. POTATOES are peeled, PROFITEROLES are filled with cream, PEAS are shelled, a GOOSE is baking in oven. Margaret is counting CUTLERY at the window.

Mr Keats has come! Margaret runs out the kitchen back door. Fanny’s hands ar covered in flour. She turns her back to her mother who unties her APRON. Fanny rinses her hands and dries them. Carefully she adjusts her hair and smooths her frock.
Margaret flies down the street and throws herself into Keats’s arms who carries her.
Do you know the difference between a caterpillar and a cheese?
A caterpillar and a cheese?
Yes.
Of course.
Then you are too old for me to carry you. Keats looks up the garden path to see Fanny, a perfect do framed at the open front door.  35 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 24.

Keats is crouched on the sitting room floor stroking the Brawne’s CAT. Fanny comes in with a TRAY of GLASSES, she shy of looking at Keats but acutely aware of him. She polishes each glass with a cloth and places it on the tab
I wondered this morning if you are sleeping in my bed.
Pardon?
Are you sleeping in my bed? Keats is confused and amazed.
No...
You see I believe you are. Have you forgot that we rented Mr Brown’s half of the house this summer while you were journeying in Scotland? Which room did you sleep in?
The one overlooking the back garden.
That was my bed. For proof, pull it out from the wall and by the pillow you will finda figure I drew with pin holes.
Is the figure you?
No. It was a fairy princess.
Should I be feeding her?

No, she refuses to eat. But what she might like is a good night poem. Mr Keats will you teach me poetry? I want to understand, but I don’t know how to begin. Margaret comes in putting a BREAD ROLL on each persons pl Keats strokes the CAT watching Fanny, the movement of her hands as she folds the NAPKINS and the angle of her head she examines the arrangement of the table.  36 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 25.

The Brawne’s sit about the DINING TABLE including the mai The meal is finished and Keats has invented a skit that compares the English and the Scottish. There are THREE CU OF TEA on the table and the maid, Toots and Fanny are bei instructed to stir their teas in different and compliment rhythms, clanging the edges of their cups with their SPOO at the end of each cycle.

The English drawing room, now the Scottish. Keats nods to Samuel who begins to play an impression of highland tune on his VIOLIN. With PLEATED NAPKINS tucked into his pantaloons kilt-like Keats does a wild impression of a highland fling. KEATS (SCOTTISH ACCENT) (cont'd) Theeey Kick and jump it and toe and go it and twirl it and wheel it, stamp and sweat and tattoo the floor! The family clap and laugh. Keats bows and removes his napkins.
Formidable, very good.
A poem!
Oh yes, a poem.

A short one. The others laugh. Fanny is quiet, watching, scared to betray her growing affection for Keats, her head bowed. Keats sits opposite and as he sits he begins to speak so naturally they are only gradually aware he is reciting.

“When I have fears that I may cease to be Before my pen has glean’d my teeming brain, Before high-piled books, in charactery, Hold like rich garners the full ripen’d grain; When I behold, upon the night’s starr’d face, Huge cloudy symbols of a high romance.”  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 25A. Fanny looks up, she and Keats are looking into each other eyes. Keats is suddenly speechless.  37 38 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 26. The family look at Keats, there is an awkward pause. KEATS (cont'd) I do apologise, I have gone blank. But Keats seems tranced.

You must be tired. Should you like coffee and cakes, we have not had cake. Mrs Brawne is getting up, clearing the table. Fanny sits opposite Keats. Neither move. Finally with wha seems an enormous effort Fanny rises and moves around the table to take Keats’s plate. As Fanny leans forward, Keat leans in towards her. As they touch, there is a suspensio of time, of breath in the room that makes even Samuel puz a moment as he loosens his bow. Keats looks up at Fanny, her irresistible closeness. He runs a finger across Fanny wrist, both confirming and breaking the spell.
“Two witches eyes above a cherub’s mouth.”
At the door everyone is saying goodbye and waving. Fanny walks out into the street with Keats.
Mr Keats have you remembered the poem?

head_text.subj: KEATS, (HE NODS AND CLEARS HIS THROAT)

text: ”“,..»Huge cloudy symbols of a high romance, And think that I may never live to trace Their shadows, with the magic hand of chance: And when I feel, fair creature of an hour, That I shall never look upon thee more, Never have relish in the faery power Of an unreflecting love; - then on the shore Of the wide world I stand alone, and think Till love and fame to nothingness do sink.” Fanny and Keats look at each other. Keats is bewitched, s is Fanny. Keats makes an awkward bow and coughing, walks into the frosty night.
In the dark hallway Fanny knocks on Keats and Mr Brown's door. Behind her Maria Dilke takes Samuel into her half o the house. Mr Brown opens the door.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 26A.
I have come for my poetry class.  39 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 27. Fanny slips under his arm.
Poetry classes! INT. BROWN’S DRAWING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY Fanny and Keats sit together. Fanny listening intently. Keats seems a little flat.
A poet is not at all poetical, he is the most un-poetical of anything in existence, he has no identity - he is continually filling some other body, the sun, the moon... Mr Brown watches disturbed.
I cannot restrain my credibility longer. Miss Brawne may I ask you a question?
You may.
Is this really you? Or are you acting?
It is really me. Keats is looking irritated.
Charles I have a pupil, desist or depart. 39 Mr Brown gets up, takes some BOOKS and his TEA CUP with h
My modest hope is the cost of the lessons will not be the poet.
The cost Mr Brown is that Mr Keats will forthwith discuss poetry with me not you as I shall study.
You don’t mean to read the poems?
I do until I know all the poets and poems in the world. I have an excellent brain and nothing to do as you have so many times noted.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 27A.
Let me bow to your ambition.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 28. Mr Brown exits.

Now Mr Brown has gone I shall find it easier to talk, he is forever scrutinising. Fanny looks at Keats. She is unsettled by his darkening mood. FANNY (cont'd) .».Can you say something of the craft of poetry? Keats’s face darkens.

Poetic craft is a carcass, a sham. If poetry does not come as naturally as leaves to a tree it had better not come at all. Fanny is writing NOTES as Keats speaks. KEATS (cont'd) I am mistaken I am not sure I can teach you.
Am I so extremely hopeless? Is it Mr Brown? I was too rude? I can apologise.
I don’t think I have the right feeling towards women. I’m suspicious of my feelings.
I don’t understand you.
If you knew what a slave to my affections I fear myself to be, and the fury it brings about in me, you might understand.
Do you not like me?

I am attracted without knowing why, all women confuse me, even my mother. I yearn to be ruined by shrews and saved by angels and in reality, I have only ever loved my sister. Fanny begins to put on her BONNET.
I am annoyed by my sister as often as I love her. And I still do not know how to work a poem out well.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 29.
You do not work out a poem. That would undo it’s magic. Poems need understanding through the senses, they develop your negative capability not rational capability.
And what is negative capability?

Your capacity for being in uncertainties, mysteries, doubts, without any irritable reaching after fact and reason. Fanny listens, not understanding. KEATS (cont'd) The point of diving in a lake isn’t immediately to swim to the shore but to be in the lake, to luxuriate in the sensation of water. You do not work the lake out, it is an experience beyond thought. Poetry soothes and emboldens the soul to accept mystery.
I love mystery.
I found your little princess, on the wall by my bed.
You could make her out?
I joined the pin pricks with my pen, she wears a butterfly frock. Shall we continue with Spencer?  40 4l 42 43 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 30.
Fanny and her family are having breakfast. BOWLS of PORRIDGE. Fanny is pouring over her POETRY BOOKS, making notes.

Maman, Mr Keats is really very brilliant, but he doesn’t like me. He prefers Toots and Samuel and even our cat who he is always petting to death. Mrs Brawne watches Fanny who has gone back to eating, wit little wonderment and concern.
Mr Keats knows he cannot like you. He has no living and no income. EXT. HAMPSTEAD STREET - DAY 4l Fanny and Samuel walk through the SNOW CLAD streets in th WELLINGTONS.
Fanny is let in at Wentworth House by Mr Brown. She is carrying a LARGE PILE of POETRY BOOKS.

Mr Keats is not here. He said to tell you he had a sore throat and thought it better to stay on in Chichester. Fanny looks very unbelieving. MR BROWN (cont'd) You do not believe me, come in. Fanny walks into their parlour. MR BROWN (cont'd) There, no Mr Keats.
May I return these books to his room? I know where it is.

Fanny makes her way to Keats’s bedroom on her own. She pu the books on his BEDSIDE TABLE.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 30A. Then sits on the BED and removes the PILLOW to see the ti PRINCESS just as Keats had said, outlined in pen.  44 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 31. Fanny trots down the STAIRS. Mr Brown waits at the bottom
I have ordered tea for us both. If you tell me what you have read, maybe I can catch up. Fanny hesitates. MR BROWN (cont'd) I’m interested...
NOTE - This scene now includes SAMUEL Warm and pretty Maria Dilke pours tea into ELEGANT LITTLE CUPS. Her son lays his head in her lap.
What Chaucer did you read?
All of it...also Mr Spencer, Mr Milton, and The Odyssey...
That is a lot to read in one week. What did you think of The Odyssey?

I am yet part way through but I have read all Mr Keats has written twice and learnt some by heart. THE EVE OF ST. AGNES “Out went the taper as she hurried in; Its little smoke, in pallid moonshine, died: She closed the door, she panted, all akin To spirits of the air, and visions wide: No utter’d syllable, or, woe betide! But to her heart, her heart was voluble, Paining with eloquence her balmy side; As though a tongueless nightingale should swell Her throat in vain, and die, heart-stifled, in her dell.” Mr Brown listens, impressed, a little smitten and also dubious of her claims.
And what Miss Brawne, did you make of Paradise Lost?
I liked it.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 31A.
You didn’t find Milton’s rhymes a little pouncing?  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 32. Fanny looks back wide-eyed at Mr Brown. Mrs Dilke looks u puzzled.
No, not very. Mr Brown regards Fanny and her wide eyes.
Is it the material of her dress that makes Miss Brawne’s eyes so violet like? Mrs Dilke sits forward to look into Fanny’s eyes. Fanny, quite pleased, opens them towards Mrs Dilke.
Oh, yes they are blue.
Violet almost.
Yes, yes. What colour are yours Mr Brown. Mr Brown BIG EYES Mrs Dilke and then Fanny.
Suitcase brown.
Samuel and Fanny walk home through the Hampstead streets.
Did you see Mr Brown? He was amazed, he was gaping.
So many authors in one week is a bit incredible
I know, he sees I am serious, and I will read them when I have the time.  46 47 48 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 33.
A MESSENGER BOY approaches Elm House with a LETTER.
Margaret climbs the steps to their bedroom.

Fanny! You have a letter. Margaret looks hard at the ENVELOPE against the light. MARGARET (cont'd) I think it is a valentine card. Fanny comes to the door. Margaret hands her the envelope. Fanny promptly shuts the door before Margaret can walk in join her. Fanny sits neatly on the end of her bed. At her feet a PATTERN is pinned out.

“The suitcase?” Oh it is from Mr Brown. Fanny is clearly disappointed and confused. FANNY (cont'd) “Darling Valentine I am not sure if you should have a kiss for your violet enchantress eyes or a whipping! Yours, the suitcase.”
Keats is pacing in the rain amidst the clothes lines outs Elm Cottage. Inside Mrs Brawne and the maid watch him from the kitchen window. Keats appears very agitated.
Fanny, Mr Keats is behaving very oddly, should I invite him inside? Fanny joins the women at the window where Keats continues vigil.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 33A.
Fanny puts on her COAT and joins Keats outside. Keats loo at Fanny who is pleased to see him.  50 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 34.
Mr Brown sent you a Valentine?
I think it is a joke. Mr Brown is walking up the road towards them. Keats sees and backs off, walking towards the Heath.
Keats! John, wait. Keats strides up the road, Fanny and Mr Brown follow him.

him 50 Fanny and Mr Brown cross the road onto the Heath, where K leads them down an AVENUE OF TREES, then across a FROST SCORCHED MEADOW to a COPSE of WINTER ELMS. No one speaks. There is gravity to Keats’s mood and an anger. Keats takes sidelong glances at Fanny.

I was away but 10 days Brown, with you encouraging me to stay on and get well. Now you send Miss Brawne a valentine card. Are you lovers, is that the truth? Keats walks off again unable to stand still. Keats walks past Mr Brown.
No John...

You sent a card Charles, you have the income to marry, where I cannot. Did you accept him Miss Brawne? Am I to congratulate you? Mr Brown moves to Keats and by putting his back to Fanny talks privately.
John, easy, it was a jest.
For whom? I do not laugh, Miss Brawne does not laugh.

I wrote the valentine to amuse Fanny who makes a religion of flirting. I am simply smoking her so you may see who she is. Mr Brown puts his arm about Keats. Keats pulls away.  51 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 35.
You disgust me.
John she is a poetry scholar one week and what, a military expert the next? It is a game, she collects suitors.

You astound me...both of you. There is a holiness to the heart’s affections, know you nothing of that? Believe me it’s not pride, it hurts my heart. Keats walks up to Fanny and stands in front of her. KEATS (cont'd) Are you in love with Mr Brown? Why don’t you speak?

She can’t speak because she only knows how to flirt and sew. Fanny walks away, humiliated. MR BROWN (CALLING AFTER HER) (cont’d) And read all Milton whose rhymes do not pounce because Miss Brawne there are none! There are one or two of her kind in every fashionable drawing room of this city “aheming” over skirt lengths. A troubled Keats takes a moment or two to decide then run after Fanny. Together they walk across the Heath.
I’m sorry. We could have a poetry lesson tomorrow. Fanny turns to him, tears streaking her face.
NO! NO! I want to dance and flirt and talk of flounces and ribbons and beading until I find my old happiness and humour. Keats is impressed by her passion. FADE TO BLACK.

A SILHOUETTE of BLOSSOMS on the Heath’s trees.  52 53 54 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 36. INT. MRS BRAWNE’S BEDROOM ELM COTTAGE - DAY 52 Mrs Brawne, Margaret and Fanny sit together on Mrs Brawne bed in their NIGHTGOWNS sipping TEA and NIBBLING TOAST fr shared plate. TREE FILTERED SUNLIGHT plays on the bed covers. Fanny is attaching the last SLEEVE to a DUSTY PINK JACKET
I was dancing, but my dress was not properly on and no matter how I hauled it up it slipped until it was around my ankles.
Did you have on a petticoat?
No, nothing.
Naked? Margaret nods and they laugh.
Did you dream Fanny? Fanny is remembering her dream but she is not telling. Th others know better than to press her.

Fanny walks along the street then up the path to Wentwort House with a WHITE BLOSSOM TWIG. She is wearing a FROCK o snowy whiteness over which she has DUSTY PINK EMPIRE LENG JACKET. She looks adorable. Behind her Samuel follows kicking a WOODEN BALL. Fanny sees Keats inside his room and taps at the WINDOW. EXT. KEATS’S ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 54 Keats leaves Mr Brown at the table and throws open the window. Fanny gives Keats the BLOSSOM SPRIG from behind her back.
I dreamed of your eyes, it is a sign I think that I do like you.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 36A.
Even though I don’t dance?  55 56 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 37. From behind Keats Mr Brown watches edgily.
Have we broken for the day? Keats? But Keats appears not even to hear. Samuel comes over to the window excited.
We are going to live next door, Mr and Mrs Dilke are moving to Westminster and we can have six months half rent!
It is a great economy for Maman. But if you like, only if you like. Keats climbs out the window. Mr Brown closes his books moodily.

NOTE - BRAWNE cat in basket for move to Wentworth House While the Dilke’s, Maria, Charles and their son move out their side of the house, the Brawne’s move in. Mr Brown a Keats are talking intensely in the GARDEN, hands behind t backs.

If the princess has already abandoned the dwarf, we cannot keep his love speech... Samuel’s BALL passes in front of them and Keats splits of kick it back. Samuel and Keats begin a game together. Keats playfully kicks at Mr Brown twice but the ball simp bounces off his legs and then Samuel and Keats pass and tackle leaving Mr Brown alone. He walks fast into the hou
The Brawne’s goods are part unpacked. Mr Brown has the family gathered in the Dilke’s old living room. Mr Brown stands at the fireplace while they sit and stand about th unsettled furniture.
If Mr Keats and myself are strolling in the garden, lounging on a sofa, staring into a wall, do not presume we are not working. Doing nothing is the musing of the poet.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 37A.
Are these musings what we common people may know as thoughts?  57 58 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 38.
Thoughts yes, but of weightier nature.
Sinking thoughts?
Not really Miss Brawne, musing, making one’s mind available to inspiration.
As in amusing?

Our thoughts are all very simple so you never need worry about interrupting us. We are always glad of company and should be happy if you joined us for dinner on any day. INT. KEATS’S ROOM/STAIRS/FANNY’S ROOM W’WORTH HOUSE - DAY Keats walks upstairs to his room. His hands behind his ba distracted with thought, the words of Mr Brown can be hea faintly from the living room. Keats walks into his room a stares at the wall. Fanny and Margaret climb up their stairs and enter their bedroom where they resume unpacking and tidying away thei CLOTHES and EFFECTS. Keats moves towards the wall and knocks. Fanny and Margaret stop still.

Mr Keats? Fanny moves towards the wall. Keats on his side again knocks a little rhythm. Fanny replies with the same rhythm from her side. Keats moves his BED against the wall. Fanny and Margaret listen to the sound of the bed scrapin and thudding against the wall.

A SPRING morning. The FLOWERS are opening their petals to early DAPPLED SUN and the BEES are busy visiting each and every bloom.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 38A. Amongst the flowers are Keats, Fanny and Margaret. They a moving between the blossoms sniffing them.  59 60 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 39. Inside Wentworth House kitchen, Mrs Brawne is helping the maid with TOAST and TEA.

Good morning, good morning. Mr Brown's fine good spirits fade when he notices Keats a Fanny amongst the flowers. Mrs Brawne joins him at the window. They watch as Fanny and Keats sniff from flower t flower. Samuel sits eating his toast.
They are sniffing every flower in the garden to find the best scent.
Mr Keats is being a bee. Mr Brown can bear it no more. He takes his tea and leaves Now Fanny and Keats are nose down in the same flower.
Fanny! I need your help. Fanny appears not to hear. Mrs Brawne goes outside but is immediately drawn into jud between TWO blooms

Mr Brown observes the dance class through the open door, before he returns to the table where he scans Keats’ writ Mrs Brawne matches Keats with Margaret but the Dance Mast changes them so Keats becomes Fanny’s partner.  61 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 40.

“Soon trembling in her soft and chilly nest, In sort of wakeful swoon, perplex’d she lay, Until the poppied warmth of sleep oppress’d Her soothed limbs, and soul fatigued away; Flown, like a thought, until the morrow-day; Blinded alike from sunshine and from rain, As though a rose should shut, and be a bud again.” Mr Brown is blinking, touched and impressed Fanny and Keats dance together, small and delicate faery people. INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - NIGHT 61 Upstairs Mrs Brawne helps Fanny dress in a NEW BALL GOWN, ever it is cleverly conceived and original. A COACH arrives and a young woman friend MARY ROBINSON wa up the path to Wentworth House. Inside Keats can hear Fanny coming down the stairs. Keats meets her in the hallway just as Fanny is greeting her friend.
Where are you going, are you keeping secrets? You said nothing of this on our walk.
It is not a secret. I am going with Mary toa dance at the Mess.
Not to dance?
Yes. Of course I will dance - why don’t you come too?
To watch as soldiers put their arms about you? Mrs Brawne comes down the stairs.
Hello Mary, you've not left yet?

I was just asking Mr Keats to join us but he is not persuaded. Keats bows and full of jealousy retreats.  62 63 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 41. ADD SOME DANCING. INT/EXT. FANNY’S ROOM/GARDEN WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 62 Fanny puts her dance sore feet on the floor of her room. opens her CURTAINS to let the morning light in and sees K lying beneath her window. Keats is looking up at Fanny.
It is a beautiful day. The HEATHER on the Heath is sprink with WILD FLOWERS. CHILDREN sail their PAPER BOATS on the POND. Keats and Fanny wait while Margaret buys an ICE CRE
Lie to me tell me you did not dance last night.

I did not sit down a single tune. You can see the truth in my slippers they are completely scuffed. I don’t think they can be wiped clean even with methylated spirits. Mama is annoyed as they are expensive but I do not know how I could have prevented it. Margaret returns with a VANILLA ICE CREAM.

May I watch the boats? I don’t want to wait again under the trees while you talk. Fanny and Keats walk together up the HILL to their favour spot shaded from the sun and prying eyes by long limbed O TREES.

head_text.subj: KEATS, (ON THE WAY TO THE TREES)

text: I had such a dream last night.
Ohhh?
I think one of the greatest enjoyments I have ever had in my life.
Well tell me.

I was floating above the trees with my lips connected to those of a beautiful figure for what seemed an age. Flowery tree tops sprang up beneath us and we rested on them with the lightness of a cloud.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 42. Keats sits back into the long grass. Fanny is rattled, jealous.
Who was the figure?
I must have had my eyes closed for I am not sure.
Yet you remember the tree tops.
Not so well as the lips. Fanny looks at Keats.
Whose lips? Were they my lips? Keats touches Fanny’s lips with his finger

They may have been yours. Keats closes his eyes and presents his lips for Fanny to kiss. Fanny gently places her lips on his. Keats waits and Fanny kisses him again. Keats pulls Fanny top of him and kisses her and she him and he her. They li down together lip to lip. KEATS (cont'd) “Pale were the lips I kiss’d.” Keats kisses her again. KEATS (cont'd) “- and fair the form. I floated with about that melancholy storm.” Margaret comes calling up the hill. Keats makes sound effects of wild flowers squealing as Margaret stops. KEATS (cont'd) “Help.” “Ahhh.” Keats slows her to a halt. To her chagrin she cannot step without crushing something.
Stop it!  64 65 66 67 68 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 43.
The three make their way across the Heath home. Keats and Fanny follow behind Margaret who plays a game of catching them touching, kissing.

Fanny, Keats and Margaret return. A glowing Keats walks backwards looking at Fanny. Keats lets Fanny pass and wat her from behind. Fanny smiles and slyly touches hands. In the garden Samuel has climbed onto the HEDGE. Mr Brown stands underneath, disconcerted by Keats’s attention to Fanny. Fanny walks in a cloud up to her room. INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - EVENING 66 Fanny lies stretched on her bed listening to her body tingling with new and beautiful sensations.
Samuel is high in the tree branches.
Mr Brown bet I couldn’t find the nightingale’s nest.

There is no nest and no bet. Keats makes nightingale trills. Mr Brown puffs his PIPE while Keats joins Samuel in the t SILHOUETTED against the last of the SUN WINKING THROUGH T LEAVES. INT. MR BROWN’S DRAWING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - NIGHT 68 Late at night Keats sits in the drawing room writing a LE to his brother George and sister-in-law Georgina when Mr Brown enters in a DRESSING GOWN with a PLATE of MIDNIGHT SNACKS. Mr Brown sits beside Keats and eats without pause
You are making a liar of me - I had just writ - “Brown is gone to bed - and I am tired of rhyming - there is a north wind blowing, playing gooseberry with the trees.”  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 44.
I read your Eve of St Agnes today it does not trip, not once, it is perfect, extraordinarily good. “Her rich attire creeps rustling to her knees:”
“Soon, trembling in her soft and chilly nest, In sort of wakeful swoon, perplex’d she lay, Until the poppied warmth of sleep oppress’d Her soothed limbs, and soul fatigued away;”

“Her soothed limbs,...” I spent the afternoon sorting through your sins and think Ode to Psyche very keen, beautiful and clear. “And there shall be for thee all soft delight That shadowy thought can win, A bright torch, and a casement ope at night, To let the warm Love in!” See here there are tears, you are so far ahead of me and above me.
Brown, I am amazed.

Your writing is the finest thing in my life. A greater miracle than to see new life born. That sort of miracle is in compare common place. Mr Brown holds out his hand to Keats who takes it. Mr Bro pats Keats hand. MR BROWN (TO KEATS’S HAND) (cont'd) You wrote this little hand.
Yes, while he was dreaming I wrote it all, see this is where the pen pressed. Mr Brown clasps the hand.
As one who truly loves you I must warn you kindly of a trap you are walking into.
If you are going to speak of Miss Brawne we have never agreed and cannot agree.
No that is not true, we both agree she is an exquisite dressed creature.  69 70 71 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 45.
Is it a sin to look well?

For one or two of your “slippery blisses” you will lose your freedom permanently. You will be slaving at medicine 15 hours a day - for what? To keep Mrs Keats in French ribbon? Keats looks dismayed, sick. MR BROWN (cont'd) I cherish your talent, I truly do.
Then allow me my happiness for I am writing again.
Keats looks up into the PLUM TREE. He whistles. The NIGHTINGALE sings.
Fanny watches Keats from her bedroom window.

Keats picks up a CHAIR from the living room table. As he takes it outside Fanny comes down the stairs and goes to Brawne sitting room where she sees Keats place the chair under the plum tree in the DAPPLED SHADE. Out of Keats’s pocket he takes a FOLDED PIECE OF PAPER an LEAD PENCIL. He does not write but becomes perfectly stil his body relaxed, his focus inward.

ODE to a NIGHTINGALE “My heart aches, and a drowsy numbness pains My sense, as though of hemlock TI had drunk, Or emptied some dull opiate to the drains One minute past, and Lethe-wards had sunk: ‘Tis not through envy of their happy lot, But being too happy in thy happiness, -” Fanny watches Keats move his chair to the shade and his p make its steady journey across the paper. Mr Brown enters his living room, he notices the chair gon then Keats under the tree one leg crossed over the other completely still except for the pen flying.  72 73 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 46. KEATS (V.O.) (cont'd) “That thou, light-winged Dryad of the trees, In some melodious plot Of beechen green, and shadows numberless, Singest of summer in full-throated ease.”

head_text.subj: THE NIGHTINGALE SINGS AGAIN THEN FLIES OUT THROUGH THE

text: Keats watches the bird’s flight then continues writing. Fanny rises and walks to the window her SEWING in hand. Keats has gone. The chair is empty. INT. BROWN’S DRAWING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 72 Keats stuffs his NOTES into a gap in the BOOKSHELF of the drawing room. Mr Brown looks up and watches as Keats walk out of the room. Mr Brown retrieves the notes. Carefully Brown lays the PAGES out on the table.

Keats is playing with the Brawne CAT. Toots stands ready a BONNET for a walk. Samuel has a BALL and CRICKET BAT. Fanny joins them, BONNET, GLOVES and PARASOL ready. Keats looks across and smiles. Mr Brown enters the drawing room unannounced, he looks ve intense.
John, can you come?
I was about to accompany the Miss Brawnes to the Heath. Mr Brown looks urgent, intent.

Now. Please. Fanny glumly undoes the BOW on her bonnet and Keats follo Mr Brown out of the room. As Fanny goes to the stairs bon in hand, she pauses. She can hear the sound of Keats’s vo and sometimes Mr Brown reading with him.

“Darkling I listen: and for many a time I have been half in love with easeful Death, Called him soft names in many a mused rhyme, To take into the air my quiet breath.”  74 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 47. Fanny opens the door softly despite Mr Brown’s sign KEEP POETS AT WORK. Keats turns and sees her. Mr Brown is at the table trying make out Keats’s handwriting as he makes a fair copy.
“Now more than ever seems it rich to die.”

“To cease upon the midnight with no pain, While thou art pouring forth thy soul abroad In such an ecstasy!” Fanny sits on a chair against the wall listening, thrille Mr Brown stops work and scrapes back his chair looking at Keats exasperated. KEATS (cont'd) What?
Did you tell Miss Brawne of our summer holiday, or shall I? Fanny looks at Keats.
Not as yet. Brown is doing his summer rental and we both have to leave.
We are meeting up on the Isle of Wight for some undisturbed writing and carousing. Fanny is burning with humiliation. Head bowed she rises f the chair and leaves.
In the DARK HALL Fanny leans against the wall and sobs. T door opens, it is Keats.
Fanny I was going to tell you.
When? When were you going to tell me? You play with me like a cat. I won’t be PICKED UP

Fanny shrieks at Keats stalking back to her side of the house. Slamming the door. Mr Brown opens the door. Samuel comes downstairs to look.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 47A. Keats knocks on the Brawne sitting room door. He lets himself in. Fanny is sobbing onto her mother’s lap.  75 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 48.
May I speak to Fanny Mrs Brawne?
NO, NO, I will not speak to him. (Shrieking at Keats) YOU HAVE HUMILIATED ME! YOU COULD NOT

head_text.subj: HAVE DONE BETTER IF YOU HAD STRIPPED ME BARE

text: Keats is white with fright.
I have no money Fanny in fact I am in debt. I must earn, I must write and make a living. If I fail though I hate to think on it, I must make way so another may marry and adore you as I wish to.

I will not be adored ever again by you or anyone! I hate you! I hate you! I HATE YOU! Keats sits, alarmed and helpless watching the sobbing Fan in Mrs Brawne’s lap. Mrs Brawne resumes her EMBROIDERY, raising her eyebrows at Keats. FADE TO BLACK.

head_text.subj: EXT/INT. BRAWNE HALF OF WENTWORTH HOUSE

text: The Brawne half of the house in it’s summer suit. DAPPLED LIGHT, YELLOW LAWN, ROSES BOBBING. The Heath beyond full MERRYMAKERS . Samuel wanders out the FRONT DOOR.
