Abigail is with child, but to whom out of shame or fear she would not say. We Brown must find out and when we have his name, butcher or baker, he shall face up to his indecency. Call her, let us get it done..
It’s not necessary. She has me believe I am the father.
My God, I had no notion of a love affair.
There was none or I must have slept through it. I woke up after some claret to find the girl in my bed snoring like a fireman.
With what ease you help yourself.  125 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 73.
It was an accident. Now she is starting a sobbing campaign to marry me. I shan’t of course.
And the child?

I have agreed to pay expenses. The worst thing is I can’t keep this place, I have to start my summer rental early. I feel wretched turning you out while you are unwell, but I haven’t anything left, only debt.

Don’t be concerned, I shall manage. In what stumbling ways a new soul is begun. INT. BROWN’S DRAWING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY Fanny quietly pours tea and moves softly amongst Keats's LITERARY SUPPORTERS and Dr Bree. She is invisible to all Keats who constantly watches her.
Gentleman I think we should hear Dr. Bree on the issue of climate for Keats health. Does he want to go to Rome?
He has to go. He won't live through another winter in England.
How do you feel about Italy John? Keats doesn’t reply
I think it’s an issue of finance.
Could we between us not start a fund or a collection? Where are we up to with the poems?
We have them in the Galley now.
Could they not generate income?
It is very hard to predict sales + eH  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 73A.
Of course he'll need a traveling companion. Brown, you’ll go?
Yes, absolutely someone must go, but I’m not sure I’1l be able to.
Is that a ‘No’?
There is an excellent English doctor in Rome, a Dr Clark, who could also find rooms for you Mr Keats.  126 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 74.
Pardon?
I am talking of a Dr Clark who attends the English colony in Rome.
Ah.
I can help find a room for the summer John if you want. At that moment a pregnant Abigail makes her way into the with a tray of hot tea. (OVERLAPPING)
Miss, Miss. But it is Mr Brown who strides irritated to the door and swiftly takes the hot pot. Abigail doesn’t move, she stay still like a stunned rabbit. The men look then look away discretely.
Which poem goes first? Is it to be Lamia or Eve of St Agnes?
It is Lamia I believe. Keats nods once again watching Fanny.

All along the street are signs of the precarious life of poor, STREET URCHINS begging, a DRUNK collapsed in the pavement. Fanny and Samuel support Keats along the road, pausing as a cough racks his body. Samuel walks a few steps behind, next to a BOY carting Keats’s TRUNK.
I want to come to Italy with you. We can marry and I’1l go with you. Sammy walk behind. Keats laughs.

My friends talk of Italy but I have no money and must yet make it through the summer in London. Besides, I don’t believe it possible I could ever leave you. Samuel is slinking up alongside Fanny and Keats.
Get back behind.
Poor Sammy, he’s not a dog.
But he will tell!
I won't tell.
You see, he listens. Keats stops.
Farewell me here.
Why?

Fanny and Keats follow the LANDLADY down a DAMP corridor a BASEMENT SUITE of TWO WATER STAINED ROOMS. There is a TABLE DIMLY LIT by the basement’s WINDOW. A SHRIEK follow by another somewhere higher in the building.
We don’t do linen. She leaves, SHOUTING back up the stairs. Keats sits at the DESK. He pretends to write. He turns to see Fanny’s look of horror. Keats looks away, shamed, steely.
Mr Hunt cannot have meant these rooms. Keats is going darkly into himself. He shakes his head.
I told you not to come. Tell me how will you fill your days when we are apart? Who will you find to smile with?  128 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 76.
No one, I will wait.

Wait? Fanny nods, confused. KEATS (cont'd) Yes you can wait, you can probably find amusements. I am not the same as you. The very air I breathe empty of you is unhealthy. You are to me an object intensely desirable. But that’s all right because you can wait! You don’t know what it is to love. It is making me glad there is such a thing as the grave!

Fanny, her mother, Samuel and Margaret and the Dilke’s ar sitting at their FORMALLY SET TABLE. All are very subdued Fanny is deeply depressed. Out of nowhere she starts to s The children and Mrs Brawne watch her anxiously. All deco is swept aside as Fanny’s sobs become convulsive. Mrs Bra waves the children away. She takes Fanny’s head in her ar stroking her tears away but they do not stop. Mrs Dilke a strokes her.
He wrote that I don’t love him. He was told I have been flirting...but I haven't.
How long has Mr Keats been gone?
Five weeks.
Perhaps it is for the best.
Whose best?
I thought it might be a relief to be separated when the circumstances are so difficult.

Everyone wishes I would give up, but I cannot, even if I wanted to I cannot. There is no one in this world so beautiful or so brilliant.  129 130 131 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 77. Mrs Dilke and Mrs Brawne exchange looks of anxiety. Toots face appears at the window. FANNY (cont'd) Get rid of her!
Margaret is outside in the garden PICKING FLOWERS when sh notices something strange under the HEDGE. A LEG, then as she cautiously circles, ANOTHER LEG and a BUNDLE beside i
Fanny approaches the tree slowly like a cat until a very Keats, barely recognisable, turns, his eyes accusing and frightened on Fanny. Keats puts an arm out to fend Fanny off.
Keep away if you do not love me, if you have not a crystal conscience this past month.
John...? Fanny does not hesitate, she kisses Keats. He is sheet wh and sweating.
I thought my heart was breaking.
You are shivering. What is this, blood? Maman! Toots, call Maman.
Hunt’s son opened your letter and hid it for two days...I’ve walked out, I’ve left them... (KEATS IS BARELY ABLE TO SPEAK)
Keats falls to one side unconscious as Mrs Brawne arrives outside.  132 133 134 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 78.

The Brawnes assist Keats towards the house The Brawne’s roll Keats gently onto a SHEET and together him upstairs and onto Mrs Brawne’s BED. INT. MRS BRAWNE’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 133 Doctor Bree is applying SUCTION GLASSES to Keats’s back. Fanny sits beside him stroking his forehead. Mrs Brawne picks up Keats’s SOILED CLOTHES from the floor.
Mrs Brawne is putting Keats’s clothes into the TUB. Fanny joins her helping to scrub the stains.
Maman may Mr Keats stay?
Yes all right, tonight.
And tomorrow? Until he leaves for Italy?
But you are not even officially engaged.
Can’t we be?
Please do not begin, there is no end to this, next you will want to marry and after that travel to Rome. It is all my doing. I should never have moved to this house. I have let this happen.
Let him stay just until Italy. I promise I shall never ever ask anything more. You will not regret it. Mrs Brawne continues to scrub.
You are already the source of so much gossip.

Well let us be engaged. He is too ill to bea threat!  135 136 137 138 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 79. INT. MRS BRAWNE’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - NIGHT 135 Fanny sits beside her feverish fiance, cooling his head w a WET CLOTH. She moves her ENGAGEMENT RING across to the fourth finger on her left hand. Her RING SPARKLES in the night. Bright Star.
VEGETABLES are being peeled and chopped. A CHICKEN BROTH strained.

INT. MRS BRAWNE’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 138 Inside Keats is dressed, lying dreaming on a DAY BED by t window. Fanny takes the tray and puts it carefully on Keats’s lap Margaret steps shyly towards Keats smiling.
Toots have you been eating rosebuds?
No, I never have.
So where do your cheeks get their blush? Fanny pulls her chair close, signalling Margaret to leave
Bye, bye. Keats begins to sip the SOUP. There is a WILD ROSE on Keats's tray. Fanny takes a PETAL and winds it around her finger.

“fold a rose leaf around thy finger’s taperdness, And soothe thy lips.” Fanny rubs the PETAL across her lips.  139 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 80. KEATS (cont'd) ...sometimes remember that I did not only dote on roses but climbed mountains and cut up bodies.

There is a small gathering of Keats’s inner circle in the Brawne living room. MR TAYLOR and MR HASLAM Keats's publishers, Mr Severn a young and very nervous painter fr and MR HUNT a loyal supporter. The tea has mostly been dr and people are preparing to leave. Fanny is quietly sewing a silk lining onto a CAP. An improving Keats sits next to her. They are very much a couple.
I confirmed your ship, the Maria Crowther sailing to Naples.
When does she leave?
In ten days. Keats winces, he looks at Fanny stops sewing, stops breathing.
Autumn is coming, it’s getting colder, I’m afraid if you delay there will be less and less reason to hope.
So there is no putting it off I must march against the battery. Mr Severn has SPILT his TEA onto his SAUCER and is neurotically dallying about what to do.
Let me pour you another.
Really, well perhaps I might just tip it back, no well perhaps not. Did I take sugar?
Yes I think you did.
Well then I did not stir it.  140 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 81.
Mr Keats tells me you are planning to paint in Rome...
We shall be in need of an Italian dictionary Mr Keats. Sorry, yes indeed I shall definitely paint. Shaking hands with Keats Mr Severn leaves. Mr Haslam says his farewell to Keats.
Mr Brown could not go?
Sadly not! I am waiting to hear but I think it not likely. Mr Haslam nods a moment thinking.
Well there is no alternative, we must put all our hope and faith in Mr Severn. A distressed Fanny continues the TINY, PERFECT STITCHES around Keats’s CAP.
Fanny is putting a TRAY together for her and Keats’s supp Mrs Brawne is SHELLING PEAS.
My God what I would do to accompany him. He is still so weak.
No. No! I have looked into it, we can’t afford the fare and if anything should happen to Mr Keats or even you in a foreign country, how could you survive?  141 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 82.
But it should not be Mr Severn he barely knows him. Where is that fool Mr Brown when he is needed? Why doesn’t he write? Fanny picks up the tray.
I have found a goose for Mr Keats’s last dinner.
Do not say “last”.

Fanny puts Keats’s arm in the correct position about her waist for a waltz. She is giggling, shaking her head happily. Beside her Margaret and Samuel stand ready excep Margaret is laughing at Keats who is clowning in his effo The dance class is happening on the lawn in the BACK GARD It’s late afternoon and the trees are casting beautiful SHADOWS across the GRASS, while the ROSES bob in the bree Mrs Brawne is at the open windows.
Ready?
Yes, please. Mrs Brawne sits back at the PIANO and begins. FANNY (cont’d) One, two, three, turn...

Two or three Posies With two or three simples - Two or three Noses With two or three pimples - Margaret and Samuel are laughing too much to keep dancing Keats is making up his own mad steps. Fanny is nimbly keeping up. KEATS (cont'd) What? Two of three Wiggles With two or three Giggles. Keats stops beside an AUTUMN LEAF. KEATS (cont'd) What’s that?  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 82A. Fanny playfully stands on it.  142 143 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 83.
Nothing whatsoever. There is no autumn in this house only summer. Please remove it. Margaret takes the LEAF by the stork like a mouse by the and drops it over the fence.

And don’t come back. Keats and Fanny dance on in their own gay way until Keats stops and lies in the grass catching his breath. He looks and sees the AUTUMN TREE TOPS. INT. MRS BRAWNE’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 142 Fanny is arranging Keats’s CLOTHES in his TRUNK. Keats is the LITTLE DESK writing in the front piece of his RED BOU POETRY BOOKS. Fanny sits back and watches him, drinking up the last mom of his presence as if he were the sun setting. Fanny move across and gently strokes Keats’s head and he, like a cat plays up to the stroking, moving his head under her palm.

The family are eating a roast goose together. The plates still full, but no-one except Samuel is eating. Fanny sta to gather the plates up. Keats brings from the SIDEBOARD RED BOUND POETRY BOOKS and puts one beside each family member. Mrs Brawne is looking at hers.
Oh my mad boy, it is so beautiful. Was ita success?
There are two highly positive reviews, by friends, six mainly positive and four hostile. I don’t know, is that successful?
Yes! Extremely so...
So they are selling well?

Why must you harp on about selling when the poems themselves are the point and they are so beautiful! Margaret and Samuel each give Keats a GIFT, Margaret a HANDKERCHIEF she has sewn.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 84.
Yes of course they are, come back and live with us, marry our Fanny, I will miss you as a son.
I love you. She gives Keats a tearful, clinging hug. Fanny puts the HAT she has been sewing on Keats's head.

It’s your old travel cap. I have sewn a silk lining to keep you warm. 144 INT. MRS BRAWNE’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - NIGHT 144 Fanny clips a LOCK of Keats’s hair and carefully folds it into a piece of TISSUE PAPER. Keats picks up the SCISSORS
Is this really happening? Are we really to separate? Keats selects a DARK CURL from Fanny and cuts it. He puts between the pages of his POETRY BOOK.
I sha’nt be able to speak tomorrow, I suspect I will break down. Let us say our goodbyes now.
I want to come to Italy with you.
And then...?
Be together.
For how long?

As long as we have. Keats sighs. Fanny begins to cry. FANNY (cont'd) Shall we awake and find all this is a dream? Is there another life? There must be, we cannot be created for this kind of suffering.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 84A. Keats puts his arms around Fanny’s neck and draws her hea him. Keats soothes her while he talks.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 85.
I doubt we shall see each other again on this earth.
Then why are you leaving? Why must you go?
Because my friends insist on torturing me with a hope they can ill afford but have already financed. It is a hopeless hope, but how do I refuse?
Say you are too ill.

“More happy love! More happy, happy love! For ever warm and still to be enjoyed, For ever panting and for ever young.” We have woven a web you and I, attached to the world but a new world of our own invention. We must cut the threads Fanny. Fanny shakes her head.
No. I can’t, I never will. Keats moves away, hitting his head with his palm.
Who do I fool? Do I wish you free? NO! NO! My still unravished bride, I should have bed you while I was well enough, why not? It could have been us with child not Brown with his bastard.
You know I would do anything...
I have a conscience! Keats is walking to calm himself in his agony. KEATS (cont'd) Then let us pretend I am returning in Spring? Fanny looks up slowly.
You will return, I know it.
Will we live in the country?  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 86.
Yes, close to Maman.
Our bedroom will look out on an apple orchard and beyond that a mountain. I am most partial to a mountain in a mist.
I will make a garden where every sort of wild flower grows. We can take our breakfast there on a little table.
We will go to bed while the sun is still high.
Then it will get dark and the moon will shine through the shutters.
And I will hold you close and kiss your breasts, your waist, your arms.
Everywhere. Keats kisses Fanny’s breasts, waist and her arms, then ru his hands along her hands until their fingers touch.
Touch has a memory.
I know it... Outside is the sound of FOOTSTEPS.
Your mother?
She won’t come in.
Fanny. I am going to bed.
I am just joining you.
And we will never separate.

Never. Not for one night. Fanny and Keats hold tightly on to each other.  145 146 147 148 149 150 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 87. INT. MRS BRAWNE’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - MORNING 145 Keats stands dressed, ready to leave. The trunk has gone. But still he stays, looking for the last time at the room which he has enjoyed some happiness. The will to go seems impossible to summon, but finally a rattling cough breaks his reverie. Fanny comes to fetch him.
Not a word. Fanny nods.
Fanny and Keats leave the house silently. Margaret runs after them. Fanny turns and desperately sha her head dissuading her from coming further. Margaret fal back.

Fanny and Keats arm in arm keep stride down the narrow la towards the Pond Street Coach Depot. Fanny looks towards Keats but does not speak. Mr Hunt walks a little apart anxiously aware of the young couples ordeal.

Amidst the SMALL CROWD at the COACH DEPOT, STABLE HANDS, CLEANERS, OTHER TRAVELLERS arriving and PARCELS and PRODU being unpacked and stacked, Keats and Fanny remain poised Finally without speaking Keats disengages his arm and squeezes Fanny’s hand. He swiftly boards the COACH. Fanny watches as he is seated then turns and leaves. Keats look out at the last of Fanny’s figure walking away. Mr Hunt climbs in beside Keats.
Fanny bursts through the door of Wentworth House. She run up the stairs into her room. Fanny opens the LITERARY POC BOOK Keats gave her and writes, “MR KEATS LEFT HAMPSTEAD.
The TREES on the Heath are almost bare and the sky is a D GREY. PILES OF AUTUMN LEAVES are BURNING, smoking the tre  151 152 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 88.

head_text.subj: INT/EXT. BRAWNE DINING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE

text: A SINGLE BLACK THREAD noses it’s way through the eye of a NEEDLE. The needle threads in and out of the BLACK MATERI Fanny is sewing. Mrs Brawne sits nearby mending. Margaret is running across the drawing room windows as Mr Brown followed by Abigail their BABY and their LUGGAGE ar back at Wentworth House.
The baby! Abigail’s baby! Oh God it has red hair!

Abigail now Mrs Brown, is taking tea in the dining room a happily showing off her baby boy to Mrs Brawne and Margar In the connecting sitting room Mr Brown stands at the win shuffling through his LETTERS from Keats, making an effor engage with Fanny who is clearly resistant. Fanny is sewi a length of BLACK RIBBON onto the black material, one nea small black stitch after another.

You saw the baby? Looks like Abigail...John’s reached Naples. They quarantined his ship. He wrote that he made more puns in two weeks out of desperation than he had in any other year of his life. I should have liked to have heard them.
You could have, had you gone - I was certain you would.
I’m planning daily but I fear I have left it too late.
Why not leave now, travel overland? Abigail walks smilingly into the room holding out the cry baby to show Fanny. Mr Brown waves Abigail and the baby away.
It’s not simple with the baby and my funds reduced, then there’s the snows...
And lack of will.  153 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 89.
Should I say it aloud? Will that satisfy you? I have failed John Keats - I have failed him. And I pay a price daily - I did not know till now how tightly he had wound himself about my heart.
What heart? You abandon your ill friend, never replying or enquiring.
Fortunately in my absence he was not short of care, his letter was full of your family’s kindness...
And my love. Mr Brown is a little stunned, moved despite himself by he open confession.
He asked me to offer whatever comfort can be given to you.
Fanny sews a seam in BLACK THREAD. Outside it is SNOWING. The DOOR BELL RINGS. Margaret answers. It is a LETTER. Sh puts it on the other end of the table.
For you Maman, it’s from Italy. Fanny stops sewing, alarmed. Mrs Brawne slowly rises and walks to the letter. She glances at Fanny who is waiting fearfully. Mrs Brawne opens the letter.
It’s from Keats in Naples. He says it looks like a dream. Mrs Brawne stops reading and looks at Fanny who shakes he head with relief and disappointment.

Why doesn’t he write to me? Fanny looks out into the garden where a bowed Brown reads letter.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 89A. 154 INT/EXT. BROWN’S LIVING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 15 Mr Brown stands at his window, looking out onto a dreary WINTER GARDEN.  155 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 90. He watches as Margaret and Samuel kick a BALL between the and beyond them the gaunt, upright figure of Fanny slowly comes into view. A mirror match in mood to himself, she paces ghostlike in the snow. Fanny and Brown lock eyes th each look away. INT. BROWN’S DRAWING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 155 Fanny knocks at Mr Brown’s garden door. Mr Brown is surprised to see her, he stands.
You once said you would offer what comfort you could.
Yes, of course, come in.
Is there something, anything at all you can read me from his letters? I am disappointed to have none of my own. Any sort of news, even the painful, brings me closer.
The latest letters are all from Severn. Keats I'm afraid, is in a deplorable state. Mr Brown sorts through his correspondence. MR BROWN (cont'd) I have some older ones from Keats.
Please.

“I can bear to die - I cannot bear to leave her. Oh, God! God! God! Every thing I have in my trunks that reminds me of her goes through me like a spear.” Mr Brown looks up to judge Fanny’s reaction. She is not shocked but transported. MR BROWN (cont'd) “The silk lining she put in my travelling cap scalds my head. My imagination is horribly vivid about her - I see her - I hear her. O that I could be buried near where she lives! I am afraid to write to her - to receive a letter from her - to see her hand writing would break my heart. My dear Brown, what am I to do? Where can I look for consolation or ease? I have coals of fire in my breast. It surprised me that the human heart is capable of containing and bearing so much misery. (MORE )

156 157 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 91. MR BROWN (cont'd) Was I born for this end? God bless her, and her mother.” The letter is to me but it is all about you - keep it. Fanny shakes her head. They look at each other with something like peace, like compassion, for what they both and for what they must soon bear. Fanny turns and Mr Brown watches as Fanny’s ghostlike fig disappears down the hall.
In the last of the light, Brown walks through the MUD SPLATTERED SNOW towards home.

head_text.subj: EXT/INT. BRAWNE DRAWING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE

text: Fanny and her mother sew while Samuel practices his VIOLI and Margaret plays happily with the CAT on the couch. The FRONT DOOR OPENING and CLOSING, then FOOTSTEPS in the hall outside attracts Fanny’s attention. She turns toward the door, poised. Mrs Brawne notices and watches the door anxiously. Samuel stops playing as a sombre Mr Brown ente the room. Fanny observes Mr Brown sinkingly, her breath suspended.
It is cold out. How are you all? Fanny notices a letter from Mr Severn in Mr Brown’s hand.
We are all quite well enough. But how is Mr Keats?

It is as unbearable to me as I know it is to you. Mr Keats has died at only 25 years. Mr Severn sent me an account, I have copied it for you Miss Brawne - shall I read it? Fanny nods. MR BROWN (cont'd) Friday 23rd February. “At four in the afternoon, Keats called me “Severn - Severn - lift me up for I am dying - I shall die easy - don’t be frightened, thank God it has come.” At one point a cold, heavy sweat broke out over his whole body and he whispered “Don’t breathe on me it comes like ice.” Keats died imperceptibly...  158 159 160 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 92.

No more. Mr Brown stops reading. Fanny makes her way shakily from the room. Mrs Brawne follows. Fanny collapses on the staircase. FANNY (cont’d) I should have been with him. I should have held him - it should have been me with him. Oh my God I am finished. He is gone. Oh Maman help me, please help me. Mr Brown and Samuel listen stricken. Margaret sits on the couch, tears dropping onto her frock.

A small funeral procession of TWO COACHES waits by the PI BERNINI FOUNTAIN at the bottom of the SPANISH STEPS. Keat COFFIN is loaded into a BLACK FUNERAL COACH. The small procession clatters through Rome’s still sleeping streets

“'Lamia!’ he cried - and no soft-toned reply. The many heard, and the loud revelry Grew hush; the stately music no more breathes; The myrtle sicken’d in a thousand wreaths. By faint degrees, voice, lute, and pleasure ceased; A deadly silence step by step increased Until it seem’d a horrid presence there, And not a man but felt the terror in his hair.” INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAWN 160 In the DIM FIRST LIGHT an exhausted Fanny is sewing her B FROCK. She makes a KNOT and CUTS the thread. Across the b are strewn KEATS'S POETRY BOOKS and his LETTERS. In the next bed sleeps Margaret, her arms about her mother’s nec who sleeps fully dressed. Fanny pulls the BLACK FROCK ove her head, one sleeve yet unmade and the hem unfinished.  161 162 163 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 93. INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAWN 161 With three chops of her big PINKING SHEARS Fanny cuts her hair short. Her BLACK HAIR falls in a circle about her fe She takes her RED BOUND BOOK of Keats’s poems 1820, her c of ENDYMION and quietly leaves the room with her BONNET a BLACK BOOTS in her hand. Mrs Brawne rises as she leaves.
Samuel! Sammy!

head_text.subj: INT/EXT. BRAWNE FRONT DOOR WENTWORTH HOUSE

text: Fanny draws on her COAT and BLACK GLOVES. She opens the f door and steps into the chilled and misty air.

Out on the Heath Fanny walks briskly through the winter M followed at a respectful distance by a hurriedly dressed Samuel. Fanny, the landscape, the trees, Samuel APPEARING and VANISHING in the FOG. Clutching her precious KEATS BO against her chest, Fanny makes her way up the side of the HILL where she and the landscape completely disappear, on her VOICE continues steadily reciting, learning by heart poem BRIGHT STAR dedicated to her.

“Bright Star, would I were stedfast as thou art - Not in lone splendour hung aloft the night And watching, with eternal lids apart, Like nature’s patient, sleepless Eremite, (devotee) The moving waters at their priest like task Of pure ablution round earth’s human shores, Or gazing on the new soft-fallen masque Of snow upon the mountains and the moors. No - yet still stedfast, still unchangeable, Pillow’d upon my fair love’s ripening breast, To feel forever its soft swell and fall, Awake forever in a sweet unrest, Still, still to hear her tender-taken breath, And so live ever - or else swoon to death.” Fanny now alone, walks on the Heath until in the dark she pauses beside the POND. Overhead the STARS GLITTER and ar REFLECTED again at her feet. FADE TO BLACK.

For three years Fanny Brawne continued to walk Hampstead Heath, often far into the night.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 94. Keats died imagining himself forgotten. Yet generation af generation of poets have been inspired by him, and his fa continues to grow.
